flow.question: Has there been a head injury, loss of consciousness, significant facial trauma, is there uncontrolled bleeding or is the airway compromised?
flow.no: Assess and control any residual bleeding by applying pressure

flow.question: Does the patient have any intraoral or soft tissue trauma?
flow.no: Self Care unless problem persists or worsens

flow.question: Does the patient have a degloving injury, large lacerations, or lacerations across the tongue?
Does the patient also have trauma to the teeth?
flow.no: Most small intra-oral lacerations do not require suturing. Advise optimal analgesia and patient to maintain good oral hygiene → Self Care unless problem persists or worsens

flow.question: Can the patient open and close their jaw and do their teeth/dentures meet together as they did before?
Is it suspected that the patient has inhaled a tooth or tooth fragment?
Has a tooth been knocked out?
Is this an adult tooth?
flow.yes: Avoid handling the root. If feasible, replace the tooth in its socket and bite gently on a cloth to hold in position. Otherwise, place in socketed tooth in milk. Note: reimplantation has better success if <6 hrs or patient is <16 yrs old → Emergency Care: Dental or NHS24
flow.no: Primary teeth are not reimplanted. Advise soft diet and analgesia (if required) → Urgent Care: Dental

flow.question: Has a tooth been broken or damaged?
Have any teeth moved?
flow.no: Self Care unless problem persists or worsens
flow.yes: Advise optimal analgesia, if required → Urgent Care: Dental

flow.question: Does the fracture involve the pulp?
flow.yes: Retain any broken pieces of tooth in water and, if available, consider covering exposed pulp with calcium hydroxide paste → Urgent Care: Dental

flow.question: Does the fracture involve dentine?
flow.no: Advise use of desensitising toothpaste to fractured surface while awaiting appointment → Urgent Care: Dental

flow.note: In many cases, further treatment is not necessary, but assessment by a dentist within 7 days is recommended. Advise soft diet and analgesia if required → Non-urgent Care: Dental
